posts.name: Brendan Manning
posts.cooked: Can you add a picture showing how this piece worked in context?

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
This year because there were no floor obstacles, and a desire for as low a CG as possible we lowered our battery part way through our belly pan.  The hole in the belly pan did a lot of the constraining, but we had a velcro strap over top just in case.  You can see in the photo how it sits lower than our 2x1 main frame rails: IMG_1318 1125×879 245 KB IMG_1319 1920×1440 164 KB

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked: Just curious, how difficult was it to do your pre-match electrical checks and to perform maintenance when parts needed to be detached from the robot, especially things wired to the bottom half of that PDP ?

posts.name: Jeremiah Orme
posts.cooked:
Those are fantastic questions, indeed! It’s important to remember that this is Version 1 of our design, and we have a lot of future changes planned for the next season. However, we found that maintenance was a bit tricky, considering the fact that we had limited access to the lower half of the PDP (Power Distribution Panel). We would often have to unbolt the PDP to gain access to it.

We also encountered a problem when a large impact with another robot broke the wall to which the PDP was attached, pushing the wires into the swerve drive module. However, this only happened during our third competition with that battery box and we have already made modifications for that particular issue.

Our drive base measures 24 x 24 inches, so others may have more space if they position it similarly. I hope this clarifies things!

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked:
That makes sense. I look forward to seeing how yall improve it for next year! It’s a really cool design for saving space and would probably work very well on a slightly bigger robot. Something you may want to consider is putting guards around your swerve gearboxes.  Our team 3D printed some when we had MK4s and they help keep the grease in and FOD/wires out.

Also, compliments to your electrical team. The wire management on that robot is impressive and looks fantastic!

posts.cooked: We have a similar strap to secure our battery that we used with a buckle to snap it and we attached it to both sides of the plate with rivets to secure it in place.
